https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/load-data.html LOAD DATAÂ interprets an empty field value differently from a missing field:

  • For string types, the column is set to the empty string.
  • For numeric types, the column is set toÂ 0.
  • For date and time types, the column is set to the appropriateÂ â€œzeroâ€Â value for the type. SeeÂ SectionÂ 11.2, â€œDate and Time Data Typesâ€. These are the same values that result if you assign an empty string explicitly to a string, numeric, or date or time type explicitly in anÂ INSERTÂ orÂ UPDATEÂ statement.

  • Fixed-size format does not work if you are using a multibyte character set.
  • With fixed-row format (which is used when FIELDS TERMINATED BY and FIELDS ENCLOSED BY are both empty), NULL is written as an empty string. This causes both NULL values and empty strings in the table to be indistinguishable when written to the file because both are written as empty strings. If you need to be able to tell the two apart when reading the file back in, you should not use fixed-row format.
